Category.title: Category
Category.description: Represents a category for organizing content within the CMS.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Category entity.

slug.description: A URL-friendly version of the category name.

Tag.title: Tag
Tag.description: Represents a tag for organizing content within the CMS.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Tag entity.

slug.description: A URL-friendly version of the tag name.

Post.title: Post
Post.description: Represents a single content entry in the CMS, like a blog post or an article.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Post entity.

slug.description: A URL-friendly version of the post title.

content.description: The main body content of the post.

excerpt.description: A short summary of the post.

featuredImageUrl.description: The URL for the post's main image.

status.description: The publication status of the post.

authorId.description: The ID of the user who authored the post.

categoryIds.description: An array of Category IDs associated with the post.

tagIds.description: An array of Tag IDs associated with the post.

createdAt.description: The timestamp when the post was created.

updatedAt.description: The timestamp when the post was last updated.

definition.description: Stores category data. `categoryId` is the unique identifier for each category.

params.name: categoryId
params.description: The unique identifier of the category.

definition.description: Stores tag data. `tagId` is the unique identifier for each tag.

params.name: tagId
params.description: The unique identifier of the tag.

definition.description: Stores post data. `postId` is the unique identifier for each post.

params.name: postId
params.description: The unique identifier for the post.

firestore.reasoning: The data structure is designed to be simple and secure. Categories, Tags, and Posts are stored in their own top-level collections. This approach is chosen for simplicity and ease of management in a CMS context. Authorization is simplified since all data is managed centrally. Security rules can be applied at the collection level to restrict creation, modification, or deletion based on user authentication.
